abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Albania Public
            Administration Reform Project (PACTA) were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was high, the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            Bank's role in promoting public administration reform
            in accession countries is delicate and essential but
            requires very strong coordination with other development
            donors, especially the EU; maintaining a narrow focus on the
            development objectives and the project design ensures
            improved supervision and allows better utilization of
            supervision resources; a divided polity requires ensuring
            commitment and ownership for reforms that goes beyond the
            Government; complementarities with adjustment operations has
            positive effects which should continue to be pursued; and
            difficult automation projects, such as the Treasury
            Management System require adequate project planning ahead of implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Public Administration Reform
            Project : sixth quality of supervision assessment (QSA6) -
            summary assessment sheet

abstracts.cdata!:
The panel finds the quality at entry of
            the Public Administration Reform Project in Albania to be
            highly satisfactory overall. The key problems encounters
            were: i) shift in government commitment, when a change in
            Prime Minister led to dilution of the earlier civil service
            law/regulations, and the protections that were built in for
            merit; ii) slow implementation progress with consequent
            delays in disbursements; iii) frequent changes in government
            Ministers making continuity of reform difficult. In the
            process it made sound use of field office staff to interact
            with the borrower on a continuous basis and to sustain the
            agencies' attention on implementation issues, again
            using the leverage of the poverty reduction support credit
            (PRSC) and related projects as needed. Finally, the team
            worked well with other key donors such as department for
            international development (DFID) to ensure that
            complementary activities were adequately funded, when they
            ran short of resources. Linking technical assistance (TA)
            loans to policy based operations is an effective way of
            ensuring that less glamorous activities of the TA get needed
            attention and are properly implemented. Also, good
            implementation requires that Bank staff work outside their
            own "sectoral silos", as in Albania.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Administration Reform Project
            aims to strengthen Albania's weak institutional and
            governance capacity. The project has four components. The
            public expenditure component addresses five elements of the
            public expenditure system, plus strengthening of the
            management of the Ministry of Finance itself: budget
            formulation; budget execution (treasury); macroeconomic and
            fiscal forecasting and analysis; accounting; procurement;
            and management of the MOF. The second component, the
            strengthening of human resource management, includes three
            sub-components: implementation of the recently enacted Civil
            Service Act; strengthening of the Department of Public
            Administration; and support of the establishment of an
            Albanian Institute of Public Administration. The third
            component, policy coordination, strengthens the capacity of
            civil service professionals to provide the council of
            ministers with policy analysis and support its coordination
            function. The last component ensures project management and
            implementation, including supporting all the required
            project administration capacities (accounting, audit,
            procurement, disbursement management, monitoring and
            evaluation) and supports several specific initiatives for
            monitoring and publicizing the intermediate impacts of the
            government's institutional and public administrative
            reform program.
